caption.p: An overview of several plants and phytochemicals with promising anti-trichomonas activity.

tr.td: polyphenol extracted from the Indian spice turmeric
possessed anti-protozoal activity two reports are suggesting a contradictory effect of curcumin on T. vaginalis
curcumin is a well-tolerated compound and is safe in at least six human clinical trials
dietary non-flavonoid polyphenolic phytoalexin
skin of grapes
inhibited the growth of T. vaginalis cytostatic effect, whereas higher doses exerted killing effects
Deleterious effects as anti-trichomonal via hydrogenosomal dysfunction and metabolic alteration
a derived anthraquinone, cuspidatum
is extracted from roots and barks of various plants like Rheum palmatum, Aloe vera, Polygonum multiflorum, and Polygonum
emodin significantly decreased the number of trichomonads in the vagina as well
cured the trichomonal abscesses, indicating good absorption of emodin anthraquinone.
Extract of leaves and twigs of both the Dorstenia species. Extracts of flowers, leaves, and stem of Rheum ribes L.
Dorstenia barteri and Dorstenia convexa extracts and Rheum ribes L.
Quercetin was found to be most potent, followed by quercitrin
anti-trichomonal activity was attributed to flavonoids, namely quercetin, quercitrin
Plants of Amaryllidaceae family
arrested the T. vaginalis cell cycle at the G2/M phase of the cell cycle
bulbs of Hippeastrum morelianum
modifications in size, shape, and intracellular localization of hydrogenosomes
arrest of the T. vaginalis cell cycle; hydrogenosome autophagy
T. vaginalis NTPDase and ecto-5′-nucleotidase activities were significantly inhibited by candimine and lycorine
oil of Amomum tsao-ko
a spice used in Chinese cuisine and is also part of the Chinese Traditional Medicine
10-fold less active than metronidazole
Cell and organelles damage, Intense morphological changes
Thai plants
Seeds, flowers, leaves, fruits
125-fold less effective than metronidazole
potent anti-trichomonal with MIC of 6.25 μM.
barks of Platanus acerifolia and Malus domestica
peels
Betulinic acid and ursolic acid
betulinic acid presented better activity than those from ursolic acid
betulinic acid: better activity than ursolic acid. Piperazine derivatized from betulinic acid: high trichomonacidal agents.
Leaves; fruit pericarp of Sapindus mukorossi
MIC for saponins was four-fold
The combination of saponin with synthetic spermicide resulted in lowering the anti-trichomonal MIC
Lavandula angustifolia and Lavandula intermedia
M. piperita and S. officinalis: anti-trichomonas activity

Comparable to metronidazole
S. officinalis was found to have higher potency as compared to M. piperita
Lavandula angustifolia and Lavandula intermedia were evaluated for their anti-trichomonal properties
aqueous extract of E. camaldulensis leaves
eradication of T. vaginalis at the end of 24 h
vaginal cream containing extract of E. camaldulensis along with extract of Viola odorata and Mentha piperita
Asteraceae and Scutia buxifolia Reiss from the Ramnaceae
The most active extracts amongst all the plants examined
Polygala decumbens 0 μg/mL.
roots
Significant effect on the viability of trophozoites.
The extract was active against metronidazole-resistant species with MIC 156
ornamental plant
effective anti-trichomonacidal
100% growth inhibition of T. vaginalis at 500 μg/mL
Carica papaya and Cocos nucifera,
anti-trichomonas effect
less effective than metronidazole
Cussonia species (Araliaceae)
Methanolic extract of leaves
Anti-trichomonas activity against T. vaginalis
MIC in the range of 0.8–1.3 μg/mL
